Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Virtual Laboratory for Engineering and Applied Sciences Education (EASE)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is creating a set of virtual reality experiments that will expose K-12 and college students, as well as the public, to laboratory equipment used in the study of materials. Some laboratory equipment can be quite expensive or cumbersome and certain experiments are time-consuming. This virtual reality approach is making technical equipment accessible at little or no cost to many more people around the world to learn about engineering and materials science, including visitors to museums and students at schools which do not own this equipment. The modules are 3-D and fully interactive to help attract more students to engineering careers. Researchers are studying how students learn from using these virtual reality modules, which will help others develop better virtual reality educational tools for other subjects in the future. Collaboration with a university in Brazil, funded through NSF's Office of International Science and Engineering, is allowing the modules to be translated and developed based on topics that will help broaden participation in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this collaborative project was to create a unique and complete set of 3D virtual reality experiments for use in an undergraduate materials science course, community college instructions, demonstrations to the general public and hands-on recruiting events for middle and high school students. The methodology and technology used made it easy disseminate to a large variety of institutions and locations; over 100 institutions requested and received the virtual laboratory for use at their site. The experiments are three dimensional and interactive, making them more sophisticated and useful than most other types of virtual laboratories.

 

Laboratories serve an important purpose in the undergraduate student educational experience. They provide the physical experience that complements the theoretical discussion in the classroom and textbook.  The advantages of a virtual laboratory include the fact that laboratory equipment can be too expensive for some institution, and certain experiments are time-consuming.

Furthermore, it may be difficult for distance education students to come to a laboratory site domestically or internationally. The virtual laboratory addresses these issues in a creative and cost effective way.

 

The project succeeded also in providing access to engineering experiments for students from disadvantaged backgrounds as well as students in programs that do not have sufficient resources for physical laboratories. It also provided access to mobility disabled students.

 

In addition to providing a modern educational tool, the large group of students that worked on the project (graduate, undergraduate, and high-school student) benefitted from professional development and training opportunities; Opportunities included training in specific software tools (such as EON, UNITY3D, JavaScript, and Studio Max3D); Work in multidisciplinary teams, at different educational levels provided an excellent experience to all students. The graduate students also were trained to become mentors, the high school and undergraduate students had their first exposure to research. The students (including the high school students) also gained experience in presenting their results in conferences and competitions in the US and abroad. The students were, for the first time, exposed to international collaboration. That included Skype meetings with groups abroad, and trips to foreign universities.
